Hi @tonybaloney! `price_hourly` is already exposed as the `price` attribute of class `NodeSize`. For the sake of uniformity wrt other drivers, I think it's ok to leave it there and don't duplicate such value in the `extra` dict.

hey @ZuluPro I'm just closing off any PRs that are >1yr old. If you want to reopen it that's fine. Some of the APIs have changed since so your unit tests probably won't pass first time

the remaining issues are almost entirely to do with encoding of fixtures. Some (e.g. aliyun ecs) have different encodings in the same fixtures folder. e.g.

outstanding bug in the azure service management driver, see:
https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1031/commits/5732852ad92d582c136ab6f7c836b262f12051bc#diff-593dee57ae65e97680b29083f4c63bb8R389

aliyun responses have been converted to ASCII. This is a bit of a hack, but since the File Fixtures module loads them into string objects, it's unavoidable without getting into a world of py2 v.s. py3 pain.

I've been banging my head against the wall on another PR and realised the 2 are related
https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1031
this was actually a bug in the Aliyun ECS driver!
ValueError: Unicode strings with encoding declaration are not supported. Please use bytes input or XML fragments without declaration

Fixed in #1031 

Thanks for the report. This was a bug in libcloud, I'm guessing that you gave the load balancer a name or description with a unicode character in it?

this is done. found 3 bugs.

- Aliyun ECS, when responses contain UTF-8 encoding and user is Python 2.7, it fails to parse the response body (fixed)
- Azure Classic driver would never list VhdImages, also list public IPs would be broken
- vSphere driver would not authenticate since 2.0

Merging

@tonybaloney is this ready to merge?

The loops in destroy_node are there so it can keep trying to delete the NIC and VHD objects, which are not actually released until some time later after accepting the DELETE request for the VM.  The current code doesn't have "while statements that never exit", they break out of the loop after a successful delete of the NIC and VHD.

I recommend restoring the retry loops but making them bounded (maybe retry 12 times with a 10 second wait between attempts).

If it's consistent with the other API endpoints then it probably should be:

```
        action = "/subscriptions/%s/resourceGroups/%s/providers/Microsoft.Network" \
                 "/publicIPAddresses" % (self.subscription_id, resource_group)
```
Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/network/publicipaddresses

Changes Unknown when pulling **69a80e57852eae5cd08e94dffe9606dbc38d698d on tonybaloney:azure_arm_fixes** into ** on apache:trunk**.
@tetron please can you change the `__init__` keyword to `region` to keep it consistent with the ec2 driver and others.
merging
this is merged. I don't know why this is still here.

Azure has two concepts: "location" and "cloud environment".  A cloud environment is a separately operated installation of Azure, it has a distinct set of endpoints and separate accounts.  Within a cloud environment there can be many locations (data centers).

When setting up a connection to Azure, it is only necessary to know the "cloud environment".  The "location" supplied in API requests that need it.

Currently `AzureNodeDriver` maps the `region` keyword to `location`, and accepts `cloud_environment` as an additional parameter which is passed through to `AzureResourceManagementConnection`.  If we renamed `cloud_environment` to `region` in `AzureResourceManagementConnection` that would give `region` an inconsistent meaning between the two classes.  

So we can either:

* Leave it as-is
* Merge cloud_environment and location into a single value for region (which gets split by the driver): user would specify `centralus` (use default) or `AzureChinaCloud/southchina` (use an alternate cloud environment). 
* Something else?
sorry that's just my lack of understand of Azure, agreed üëç  merging.

So the issue was the connect() would always be called in <2.0, because it meant something in httplib. Now requests is a higher level API so connect is only called lazily if the connection instance hasn't been set. In the case of the openstack auth, it has. So the host property would be loaded at init but then when the catalog is fetched, the property doesn't trickle down to the instance of the requests session.
Adding `connect()` to each call for the internal method that unpacks the catalog would fix this issue but might add a small overhead to each call since it's in morph_action_hook. But that takes it back to the speed of <2.0 anyway.

@tonybaloney looks like the tests pass, if this gets pulled in do you know when the next RC version would be released?

@tonybaloney Is there a caching model for libcloud?

The `.list_images` method takes 25+ minutes to populate a pretty-printed 2.1MB JSON file of all the publicly registered Azure images. It's doing 1 request per image. Using cPickle the result was 1.3MB.

If you like, I can put this code into the library as an `ex_cache_dir=` which will set caching to True and put the files in `path.join(ex_cache_dir, 'azure_arm_{location}_images.pkl')`. I'll add a `ex_cache_force_refresh=` to invalidate the cache and reload it.

It takes way too long otherwise :hourglass_flowing_sand:
